content.description: First climb to the right of Decepticlips, shares an anchor with it.  Follow the bolts trending left.  Best way to set up a top rope for Decepticlips.
content.protection: 5 bolts, two bolt anchor with rings

content.description: One of two very enjoyable slabs at tree fort, this is likely the best route of the area. While soft for the grade, there are some pleasant moves and some friction required high on the route.
content.location: Walk from the trail and head right, stay high before you walk to the very short climbs around the corner. You start on a sort of dirt plateau. Start with a traverse to the left.

content.description:
A second long route, and the longest at the cliff, this route isn’t worth the time. Steep moves at the bottom and easy climbing to the finish. Kelsey recommends traversing into There be Potentialat the second bolt. 

 Note: a 70m rope BARELY makes the ground
content.location: Right on There Be Potential second route when you descend into the tree alcove.

content.description: A long route that’s enjoyable. The crux is at the bottom, it’s steep but has good holds and better feet. Once you climb this steep section the climbing eases off considerably to about 5.5 scrambling with some bolts. Rated 5.8 in the guide, this is soft for the grade.
content.protection: 7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor shared with Lost Treasure
content.location: From Glaks, continue around the corner this route is the first once you descend into a small alcove of trees.

climbs.name: Something Fishy
climbs.fa: Kris and Jill Klein, Shasta Miller, Kelsey Gray

content.description: This route is short but somehow still worth it. Take a right at the second bolt, going up and left is actually harder and a fall will smack you on to the slab. The slab is a delicate move then its off to bigger holds to the top.

climbs.name: Sightless Monkey
climbs.fa: Chelsee Jane, Ilya Shestakov, Kelsey Gray 2014

content.description: Climb steep ground on thin holds to a clean upper slab.  Move left to share the final bolt with Ilya’s 8.
content.location: Second climb from the left on Glak’s Place.

content.description: The right hand slab just next to tree tackle. While not as good as it’s neighbor, this is a pleasant route to take newer climbers on.
content.location: Start in the dirty alcove to the right of the main walls, climb right following the bolts.

climbs.name: Ilya’s 8 5.7
climbs.fa: Ilya Shestakov, Chelsee Jane, Kelsey Gray 2014

content.description: A fun 5.7 for new lead climbers.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with a walk-off
content.location: Left most bolted route on Glak’s Place.

content.description: Is best as a toprope when climbed direct as the lower section was not solid enough for a bolt.  Consider bringing a stick clip for ground fall protection.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.  Consider bringing a stick clip to clip the first bolt if leading or set a toprope.
content.location: Is the 4th route on Glak’s Point and 1 of the 4 “Transformer” named routes!

content.description: A short route that climbs awkwardly and isn’t all that enjoyable.
content.location: This short route is climbs the corner next to Trap Door.

pathTokens: Tree Fort Area and Glak’s Place, The

content.description: Glak’s Place is a great place to get away from heavy wind and climb some short, fun sport routes off the Seward Highway.  The first two routes were put up by Ilya Shestakov and Chelsea Jane as both their first lead and first FA after many hours of cleaning. (According to the Alaska Rock Climbing Guide, 3rd edition, by Kelsey Gray)
